metadata.title: Legal and practical challenges in classifying nanomaterials according to regulatory definitions

sections.text:
PersPective https://doi.org/10.1038/s41565-019-0396-z
1University of Vienna, Department of Environmental Geosciences, Vienna, Austria. 2University of Vienna, Department of Business Law, Vienna, Austria. 3University of Vienna, Research Platform Nano-Norms-Nature, Vienna, Austria. 4University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, Vienna, Institute of Law, Vienna, Austria. *e-mail: antonia.praetorius@univie.ac.at; thilo.hofmann@univie.ac.at
Nanomaterials are a popular object of environment, health and safety research, both from a legal and a practical perspective. While the applications of nanomaterials are extremely promising, their widespread presence in everyday products has raised concerns about potential risks and demand for adequate regulations. In the European Union, different legal acts contain specific provisions for nanomaterials1–4, including several product-specific regulations, such as for Cosmetics5, Food6, Biocides7 and Medical Devices8. Furthermore, a recent revision9 of the REACH Regulation on chemical substances10, which will apply as of 2020, introduces nano-specific provisions in the annexes. The scope of these regulations is specified by different definitions of the term “nanomaterial” since 2009 (see Table 1 and Supplementary Information Section 2). The Cosmetics, Food and Biocide Regulations contain their own individual nanomaterial definitions, whereas the Medical Devices and REACH Regulations define nanomaterials (or “nanoforms” in the case of REACH) according to the definition proposed by the European Commission in the Recommendation 201111 (see Table 1). It is crucial to note that—even though the Commission’s recommendation has attracted much attention and may even have been discussed more than the regulation-specific definitions12–17—the Recommendation 2011 in itself is a non-binding instrument. It puts no obligations on product manufacturers. Conversely, regulations are legally binding and directly applicable in the member states of the EU.
Nanomaterial classification and regulation implies a twofold challenge. On the one hand, lawmakers must provide a meaningful legal framework including sensible definitions of nanomaterials; on the other hand, adequate analytical techniques are required to identify nanomaterials as defined by the regulations and to prove their presence in a product. The legal debate is embedded in a dynamic development, both from a regulatory and from a practical perspective. The Commission’s Recommendation 2011 has led to several reports on the definitions as well as the corresponding scientific background18–20. Furthermore, the Commission conducted a Public Consultation in 201721. ‘Adaptation clauses’ within
the abovementioned regulations authorize the Commission to alter the current definitions by way of delegated acts, provided that the changes concern solely technical or scientific questions22,23. At the same time, there has been an immense effort in developing analytical methods for nanomaterial detection, quantification and characterization in product samples12,17,24–32 and the environment33–43. Considerable progress in nanomaterial-specific analytical methods has been achieved within recent years12,44–49, also due to the initiatives taken on the EU level as well as corresponding project funding.
This Perspective takes an interdisciplinary approach to address both the legal and the practical dimensions of nanomaterial regulation, and analyses different elements (Supplementary Table 1) of current “nanomaterial” definitions at the EU level. Using interpretation techniques in accordance with the prevailing legal methodology, we provide a critical assessment of the legal clarity of the individual nanomaterial definitions and discuss the workability of the regulatory framework in light of existing analytical techniques.
To interpret EU law, the European Court of Justice usually refers to the text of the provisions in question, taking into account its aim and purpose; moreover, it considers the different language versions of the text, which are all equally binding50–52. In rarer cases, the court has examined the drafting history53. These methods are helpful when dealing with general terms and ambiguous definitions, although some uncertainties may still prevail.
Likewise, the exact classification of nanomaterials in complex samples (that is, consumer products or the environment) is no trivial task28,43. Difficulties arise from the fact that nanomaterials cannot be classified by an unambiguous substance identity54 (like, for example, lead or phenanthrene) but represent materials composed of substances possessing several properties (such as size, shape, composition), which are determined not by one single value but a distribution of values.

sections.heading: Elements of the definitions
sections.text:
Below, we take a closer look at specific elements of the “nanomaterial” definitions.
Legal and practical challenges in classifying nanomaterials according to regulatory definitions Martin Miernicki 1,2, Thilo Hofmann 1,3*, Iris Eisenberger3,4, Frank von der Kammer 1 and Antonia Praetorius 3*
The European Union (EU) has adopted nano-specific provisions for cosmetics, food and biocides, among others, which include binding definitions of the term “nanomaterial”. Here we take an interdisciplinary approach to analyse the respective definitions from a legal and practical perspective. Our assessment reveals that the definitions contain several ill-defined terms such as “insoluble” or “characteristic properties” and/or are missing thresholds. Furthermore, the definitions pose major and so far unsolved analytical challenges that, in practice, make it nearly impossible to classify nanomaterials according to EU regulatory requirements. An important purpose of the regulations, the protection of human health and the environment, may remain unfulfilled and the development of innovative applications of nanomaterials may be facing a path full of (legal) uncertainties. Based on our findings, we provide five recommendations for a more coherent and practical approach towards the regulation of nanomaterials.

Size and structure. It is obvious that size and structure are the most important elements of the aforementioned nanomaterial definitions. Even though it is commonly acknowledged that many properties of materials are size-dependent55,56, the fixed threshold between 1 nm and 100 nm was introduced rather for regulatory than for scientific reasons in order to provide clear instructions57. All definitions listed in Table 1 cover the size range 1–100 nm (10–9 m) (Fig. 1). No lower size limit is specified by the Novel Food Regulation, whereas the Cosmetics Regulation is the only regulatory act stating a clear lower limit of 1 nm. In the case of the Biocide Regulation and the Recommendation 2011, the specified lower limit of 1 nm appears somewhat flexible, as both definitions explicitly include nanomaterials smaller than 1 nm, but only if they are fullerenes, graphene flakes or single-wall carbon nanotubes. These can indeed exist with dimensions as small as 0.4 nm (refs. 58,59). It is not specified whether other, non-carbon-based materials would also fall under these definitions if they have one or more dimensions less than 1 nm, but none within 1–100 nm.
In addition to size, the specific definitions differ subtly with respect to material structure (Fig. 1). The Recommendation 2011 and the Biocide Regulation have the narrowest scope in this respect: they refer to “materials, containing particles”, and apply where these particles have at least one external dimension in the nano-range. They also apply to aggregates or agglomerates larger than 100 nm, if those are formed by such particles. In contrast, both the Cosmetics Regulation and the Novel Food Regulation do not explicitly refer to “particles” but rather to “materials” with external dimensions or internal/surface structures in the required size range. This covers the same materials as the Recommendation 2011 and the Biocide Regulation, because a material containing particles with external dimensions in the nano-range is in itself a material with internal structure in the nano-range. It is important to note that both the Cosmetics and the Novel Food Regulation in principle also apply to materials containing no particles, but, for example, porous structures in the nano-range (Fig. 1). The Novel Food Regulation goes even further and plainly includes “structures, agglomerates or
aggregates” larger than 100 nm, if they retain properties “characteristic of the nanoscale”.
As all relevant definitions apply to nanomaterials from 1 to 100 nm, analytical methods for size determination must practically be capable of providing reliable information down to 1 nm. However, size detection limits and related problems have been reported both for microscopic14,47,60,61 and spectrometric methods12,44–47. These limitations also apply to single-particle inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (spICP-MS)62, which has gained considerable attention in recent literature. Size detection limits represent the lowest size at which a method can reliably detect a particle. Particles below the size detection limit are effectively invisible to the instrument (Fig. 2). Such limits are typically affected both by the target material (that is, elemental composition of the nanomaterial) and by the product matrix. For spICP-MS, for example, size detection limits generally lie around 10–50 nm depending on the targeted major element and instrument capabilities; sometimes considerably higher for certain materials, for example nanomaterials composed of silicon or titanium62,63. This means that the smallest particles are the hardest ones to detect, which is concerning given that nanoproperties are likely to be most pronounced for materials on the lower end of the nano-range55,56.
Particle associations and aggregates pose additional analytical challenges. For instance, the differentiation between a particle larger than 100 nm, which is not considered a nanomaterial by any of the definitions in Table 1 and a larger than 100-nm agglomerate or aggregate of 1-nm to 100-nm sized particles, which would be considered a nanomaterial under all three regulations, requires analytical tools capable of assessing the inner structure and type of particle–particle bonding in the material. Only certain imaging methods, such as electron microscopy, can provide such insight. Experienced operators are required, because particle shapes can be ambiguous, leading to considerable inaccuracies48. The fact that the morphology of particles can change in response to the surrounding conditions additionally complicates analysis. Other approaches, like fractionation methods (for example field-flow fractionation), do not

distinguish between particles and aggregates of the same size or different particle shapes that may have the same average hydrodynamic diameter27. The same holds true for spICP-MS, which only detects total particle mass, with no information on shape/structure38.
Size distribution. The request to acquire the size distribution of the nanomaterial acknowledges that most materials are not monodisperse—that is, that they contain particles of variable size64,65. Although a common way to express such distributions is to measure the contributions of the different size fractions to the total mass (particle mass-based size distribution), the Biocide Regulation and Recommendation 2011 explicitly require the determination of the particle number-based size distribution. This means that particles in the critical size range are counted and compared to the total
number of particles to account for the fact that small mass fractions can contain the largest number of particles (Recommendation 2011 Recital 8). Materials with a number-weighted median particle size between 1 and 100 nm are classified as nanomaterials48, that is, the threshold is set at 50%.
No explicit size distribution requirement applies to food and cosmetic products. This leaves room for interpretation as long as the regulations are not aligned with the Recommendation 201166. At least for food, alignment can be expected67 (see also Supplementary Information Section 2). Under the Cosmetics Regulation, it may be necessary to determine the particle-size distribution of a nanomaterial for a safety assessment66,68. The underlying question remains: when does a material qualify as a nanomaterial? We believe that the regulations on food and cosmetics contain an implicit size

This is particularly true for a sample with low nanomaterial concentration25. With increasing width of the size distribution, the number of particles to be sized increases to ensure that a representative subsample of the material has been covered. Usually the sizing and counting process is continued until the mean and width of the determined distribution remain constant within a pre-defined limit. Appropriate software can assist the analysis71, but experienced staff and standard procedures are needed to minimize the danger of operator bias48.
Single-particle ICP-MS shows great promise as a particle counting technique that determines number concentrations directly. However, corresponding particle sizes are obtained by conversion from mass, which is only reliable if particle shape, density and exact composition are known35. Finally, as discussed above, the limitation to particles with sizes above the size detection limits poses a hindrance to both electron microscopy and spICP-MS (Fig. 2a,b). A material with an actual particle size distribution in which 15% of the particles have a size between 1 and 30 nm, 38% between 30 and 100 nm, and 47% larger than 100 nm would qualify as a nanomaterial under the Recommendation 2011 and the Biocide Regulation (>50% of the particles fall in the range of 1–100 nm) (Fig. 2a). However, if the characterization method used had a lower size detection limit of around 30 nm, the smallest fraction of particles would be missed in the measurement. As a result, the median of the number size distribution would be shifted to >100 nm (Fig. 2b), leading to the material in question being incorrectly classified as non-nano.
In cases in which a characterization method does not determine the number-based size distribution directly (by counting the particles), indirect measurements are possible which include a conversion step. For instance, dynamic light scattering determines a (scattering) intensity-based size distribution, whereas the distributions derived from fractionation methods (for example field-flow fractionation) coupled to an ICP-MS instrument are mass-based48,49. The conversion is often complex and based on assumptions that might introduce a considerable risk of errors19,48. Since the mass of particles of the same substance scales with the cube of the particle size, the largest errors originate from the conversion of the mass of the particles at the smallest end of the size distribution (Fig. 2e,f). Small fluctuations in measured mass units can lead to immense variations in determined particle numbers. For example, a noise signal at a size of 10 nm, corresponding to less than 0.1% in total mass, can lead a material containing less than 20% of <100 nm particles (Fig. 2c,d) to appear to be composed of close to 70% of particles below 100 nm (Fig. 2e,f). Additionally, a common assumption is the spherical shape of particles when converting mass based to numberbased distributions. Errors can be introduced if the nanomaterials possess a different shape, for example being needle-shaped60,72. The more inhomogeneous the material is in terms of dispersity and particle shape, the more challenging the analysis.
In this context, it is noteworthy that the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) introduced, in an amendment to Federal Regulation 40 C.F.R. § 704.20, new reporting and recordkeeping obligations when chemical substances are manufactured or processed at the “nanoscale”73. These obligations apply to chemical substances defined in Section 3 of the Toxic Substances Control Act74 in the size range 1–100 nm, provided that they exhibit unique and novel properties. Interestingly, the definition excludes substances consisting of less than 1% of particles (associations) between 1–100 nm, measured by weight. Given the challenges related to detection limits for the lower end of the number size distribution discussed above, a weight-based threshold seems to be the more pragmatic and practical approach. In most cases (when particles are present in a continuous distribution), if a material contains >50% of particles in the number size distribution in the specified size range, it will also lie above the 1% weight threshold. This 1% mass-based threshold may often be in fact more conservative than the 50% numberbased threshold (see, for example, Fig. 2d).
Finally, volume-specific surface area determination (Supplementary Information Section 3) has been suggested as a proxy for nanomaterial classification, although only in the Recommendation 201111.
Origin. The Recommendation 2011 applies to “natural, incidental or manufactured” nanomaterials. “Natural” materials occur in the environment without human intervention (for example volcanic ashes, clay minerals). “Manufactured” usually refers to materials made for a specific purpose; “incidental” means materials resulting from a human-induced process with a purpose other than producing nanomaterials—for example combustion processes65. The Cosmetics Regulation and the Novel Food Regulation have the narrowest scope: they apply only to “intentionally manufactured” and “intentionally produced” materials. This clearly excludes materials of natural origin, and the addition of the term “intentionally” reinforces that incidental materials are not covered either (compare with ref. 75). Overall, it appears that the term “manufactured” as used in EU law does not necessarily mean that a material was made for a specific purpose, because otherwise the addition of the term “intentionally” would be unnecessary.
Interestingly, the Biocide Regulation, unlike the Recommendation 2011, refers only to “natural or manufactured” substances. It is noteworthy that the European Parliament’s resolution76 on the proposal by the Commission77 included only “intentionally produced materials”, as in the Food Information Regulation (see Supplementary Information Section 2). The later inclusion of the term “natural” indicates the legislator’s intention to broaden the scope of the Biocide Regulation in the vein of the Recommendation 2011. It remains unclear whether the omission of the term “incidental” aims to limit the scope of the regulation or whether the term “manufactured” within the meaning of the Biocide Regulation refers to all materials made by humans, intentionally or not. Against the background of the drafting history of the Biocide Regulation, we believe that the latter conclusion is more reasonable.
It is very challenging to establish the origin of a material experimentally. Not only does it require knowledge about the inherent differences between materials from distinct sources, but it also requires the analytical capabilities to do the differentiation. Such differences can lie in the different coatings detected by transmission electron microscope (TEM) analysis43,78. Another strategy is the comparison of element ratios which can differ significantly between manufactured and natural nanomaterials33. Unfortunately, this approach often requires specialized instruments, such as an inductively coupled plasma time-of-flight mass spectrometer (ICP-TOFMS), capable of multi-element analysis on individual particles, which makes such measurements very costly and far from routine analyses39,79. A natural background of nanomaterials is also commonly found in products—for example, natural nano-sized silica particles in food80. However, available analytical methods usually can only determine the total silica content without distinguishing the different types of particles28.
Two basic strategies are conceivable: either the determination of the material’s origin can be attempted through a lengthy and complex analysis of certain of its properties (coating, element or isotope ratios, shape); or it is possible to work on assumptions. For instance, if a product sample contains a certain well-defined material commonly used in the industry, it can be assumed that this material is of technical origin. This approach requires knowledge of industry standards and fails with regard to recently developed materials. The most critical task, however, is the determination of “intention”. Except for nanomaterials with a very specific functionality exclusive to the nano-range and essential to the product in question, we see no reliable and practical way, for actors other than the product manufacturer, to prove the intentional production of a material.
NATurE NANoTEcHNoLogy | VOL 14 | MARCH 2019 | 208–216 | www.nature.com/naturenanotechnology212
PersPectiveNATUrE NANOTEcHNOlOgy (In)solubility/biopersistence. The nanomaterial definition of the Cosmetics Regulation is the only one limited to “insoluble or biopersistent” materials. The terms insolubility and (bio)persistence, which seem to be used interchangeably by the Cosmetics Regulation, are generally describing the potential for degradation into molecular components accompanied by a loss of nanofeatures66. As a consequence, materials in the nano-range used in cosmetics but not considered to be insoluble or biopersistent (liposomes81, for example) fall out of the scope of the definition66.
From a scientific perspective, when speaking of “insoluble” or “biopersistent” materials, one actually refers to very low solubility or low rates of dissolution or dissociation, not absolute insolubility. In principle, various methods exist to determine solubility (thermodynamics) or dissolution rates (kinetics)82, including dialysis devices83, centrifugal/filtration methods84,85, spectroscopic86 and imaging87 techniques. However, most of these methods have been developed for samples in relatively simple (aqueous) matrices. It is important to note that the properties of the surrounding environment (such as chemical and biological composition, pH and temperature) will strongly influence the solubility of a given nanomaterial82. Unfortunately, the definition in the Cosmetics Regulation neither provides clear threshold values for solubility/dissolution rate (or biopersistence) nor does it specify the required testing conditions. Should this definition be interpreted as applying to nanomaterials insoluble within the actual product, available methods will have to be assessed for their applicability in complex matrices and are likely to face considerable challenges. Furthermore, testing nanomaterial solubility within the vast range of potential media that the nanomaterial may encounter during the product’s life-cycle (product matrix, different environmental media, bodily fluids) will quickly overstrain available resources in time and money.
We think it is unreasonable to exclude a material from the definition used in the Cosmetics Regulation on the off chance that the material degrades or dissolves under some (extreme) conditions it may encounter during its entire lifetime. This reading would probably exclude a wide range of materials from the regulation’s scope or allow producers to apply their own interpretation and thresholds88 and would thus potentially run counter to its aim. To provide clarity regarding the meaning of the terms “insolubility” and “biopersistence” in the Cosmetics Regulation and to develop an analytical testing strategy, the criteria need to be clarified by providing reference conditions and solubility thresholds.
Characteristic properties. The Novel Food Regulation subjects structures, agglomerates and aggregates that have a size greater than 100 nm to the nano-specific rules if they “retain properties that are characteristic of the nanoscale”. Practically, this means that two groups of materials must be examined. On the one hand, it includes materials that are smaller than 100 nm (no further analysis as regards properties necessary). On the other hand, applied in a strict manner, it means that every material found in the sample with a size above 100 nm needs to be tested against characteristic properties of the nanoscale.
It is hard to define “nano-characteristic” properties in a general fashion. The EFSA states that an increased rate of dissolution or degradability of nanomaterials to non-nanoforms as well as the presence of strongly bound aggregates may indicate loss of nanoproperties89. The Novel Food Regulation mentions the large specific surface area and physico-chemical properties, which differ from the non-nanoform of the same material. The large specific surface area could represent a clear criterion, because it directly translates into a specific size for spherical nanomaterials. Here, a clear threshold value would assist compliance with the regulation. However, the second criterion of distinct physico-chemical properties is very vague. Overall, from a legal perspective, it seems that the “specific properties” criterion is not applicable in the vast number of cases in
which there are no commonly acknowledged “nano-specific” properties of a given material. In light of the missing clarity about what constitutes “properties characteristic of the nanoscale”, it is impossible to discuss available analytical methods to test for this criterion.

sections.heading: Further practical challenges
sections.text:
Several studies have outlined generalized approaches for the design of characterization procedures for nanomaterials in complex matrices17,28,90,91. A vital aspect of the quantification process is adequate sample preparation (see Supplementary Information Section 4 for examples), which needs to be tailored to the requirements of the characterization methods used, as well as to the properties of the product to be analysed. The aim of any sample preparation procedure is to ensure that the nanomaterials are not changed during the preparation process—agglomerated, dissolved or chemically altered, for example. If only the size distribution is of interest, chemical alteration may be acceptable as long as the size distribution is not changed. Additionally, sample size and selection need to provide a high degree of representativeness of the analysed product, for example by establishing clear guidelines for sample homogenization (such as mixing, shaking or ultra-sonication), the minimum amount of sample to be analysed and the number of replicates.
Organic nanomaterials are generally less frequently examined in the selected product groups than their inorganic counterparts. However, their usage is increasing92. Their characterization can be particularly challenging, as common sample preparation methods such as matrix digestion will not leave the organic nanomaterials intact. Furthermore, most measurement techniques for inorganic nanomaterials, such as ICP-MS, cannot be applied to organic matter90,93 and organic particles might lack the necessary contrast in electron microscopy methods. Specific analytical strategies have yet to be developed, for example based on tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, nanoscale Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy or nanoscale NMR.

sections.heading: Interpretation of the definitions
sections.text:
Clearly, interpreting the different EU definitions of nanomaterials can be difficult, and our legal analysis has revealed that many ambiguities cannot be easily resolved. These challenges relate especially to the necessary threshold values for the assessment of the size distribution or the solubility of a material in question. The Cosmetics Regulation and the Novel Food Regulation seem to be most problematic, as they contain terms such as “insoluble/biopersistent” or “nano-characteristic properties” that are extremely difficult to interpret. Interpretative flexibilities occur in numerous fields, and it is the task of lawyers and judges to work with them. However, the substantial legal uncertainties revealed in the present assessment stand in the way of safe development and implementation of nanotechnology. Even where EU guidance documents exist, legislative clarification would be desirable to enable the development and consistent implementation of industry standards.
In principle, it makes sense to apply different nanomaterial definitions in different regulations. One might, for example, want to take a more conservative approach for products ingested by humans. This may explain why more materials are covered by the Novel Food Regulation’s definition than by the others (Fig. 1). However, not all divergences between the definitions are justified. For instance, we see no reason that “nano-characteristic” properties should be more important for food than for cosmetics: both come into direct contact with the human body. Given that the initial regulatory proposals of the Commission did not contain definitions of nanomaterials, and that such definitions were only introduced by the European Parliament or the European Council (see also ref. 94 and Supplementary Information Section 2), one might wonder whether the Commission will use the adaptation clauses contained in the regulations to align the definitions.
NATurE NANoTEcHNoLogy | VOL 14 | MARCH 2019 | 208–216 | www.nature.com/naturenanotechnology 213
PersPective NATUrE NANOTEcHNOlOgy It is worth noting that these clauses introduce considerable flexibility because no legislative procedure is required to amend the definitions. The standards for the adaptations, however, are not uniform and suffer from vague wording; and although apparently presumed by the legislator, amendments of this kind are not merely technical or scientific questions. Definitions of nanomaterials determine the scope of legal obligations and sanctions and are, first and foremost, politically decided22. The problem is mitigated by the fact that the European Parliament and the Council have the power to revoke the Commission’s authorization or to object to adaptations.

sections.heading: Implementation of the definitions
sections.text:
Despite considerable advances in methods, the limitations of the available analytical tools generally prevent a full assessment of product samples for nanomaterial classification under the regulatory requirements. The cornerstone of the problems observed relates to the determination of the size and the number size distribution as well as the challenges associated with detection limits for small sizes. Only a combination of different characterization methods can currently permit a comprehensive identification, quantification and characterization of nanomaterials12,48,93. Such a combination could, in principle, demonstrate that the implementation of the definitions is possible in specific cases, although the need for clear frameworks and guidance is frequently highlighted.
Implementation in principle does not equal implementation in practice. The resources required for such analyses (availability of equipment and validated methodology, instrumental settings, trained staff) are considerable. Moreover, it will be necessary to adapt the implemented protocols to different types of (consumer) products. In sum, the implied costs and the required time are likely to overstrain public enforcement authorities, which must apply the definitions daily. Criteria other than the size (distribution) requirement—that is, origin, solubility, specific properties of nanomaterials—are rarely assessed by the relevant literature. This may be due to the unclear meanings of these requirements. Our assessment has shown that the analytical options for determining the origin of nanomaterials are unsatisfactory. Whether the implementation of the criteria of solubility and specific properties of nanomaterials is feasible depends on the meaning one attributes to these criteria; in any event, a case-by-case assessment will be necessary.
Five recommendations for the regulation of nanomaterials Apart from instrumental limitations, the cost–benefit relation is a major obstacle to the practical enforcement of the regulatory requirements relating to nanomaterials. Where practical enforceability of the regulatory framework is not ensured, legal consequences cannot be applied. A limited understanding of the exact wording of the definitions and their possible interpretations may be detrimental to the efficient development of adequate analytical methods and tools. Continuous assessment and further development are certainly necessary both on the legal and on the practical side. In sum, it seems that the EU regulatory requirements regarding nanomaterials are ‘ahead of their time’, as they prescribe conditions that are nearly impossible to satisfy in practice by using current analytical methods.
In view of the conclusions drawn above, we make the following recommendations for the regulation of nanomaterials. These recommendations aim not only to benefit European law, but also to serve other jurisdictions in which legal approaches to nanomaterials are discussed. (1) The nanomaterial definitions should be clarified by avoiding
ill-defined terms and by including clear thresholds (for example for solubility in the Cosmetics Regulation) for the sake of legal certainty and workability of the regulations.
(2) Nano-specific regulations that are not workable in practice cannot fulfil their function, for example to protect humans and the environment, and thus need adaptation. (3) The adaptation clauses should be harmonized and include clearer distinction between technical/scientific aspects to be adapted by the Commission and political/risk management aspects that should remain within the responsibility of the legislator. (4) Product manufacturers should carry the burden of proof for the nanomaterials’ origin. (5) The 50% by number threshold should be replaced by a threshold of 1% by weight to make the definitions workable with current particle analysis methods and thereby contribute to a more balanced cost–benefit relation in the regulatory nanoframework and its enforcement.

referenceMentions.context: (1) The nanomaterial definitions should be clarified by avoiding ill-defined terms and by including clear thresholds (for example for solubility in the Cosmetics Regulation) for the sake of legal certainty and workability of the regulations.
(2) Nano-specific regulations that are not workable in practice cannot fulfil their function, for example to protect humans and the environment, and thus need adaptation.

(3) The adaptation clauses should be harmonized and include clearer distinction between technical/scientific aspects to be adapted by the Commission and political/risk management aspects that should remain within the responsibility of the legislator.
(4) Product manufacturers should carry the burden of proof for the nanomaterials’ origin.

metadata.abstractText: 1University of Vienna, Department of Environmental Geosciences, Vienna, Austria. 2University of Vienna, Department of Business Law, Vienna, Austria. 3University of Vienna, Research Platform Nano-Norms-Nature, Vienna, Austria. 4University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, Vienna, Institute of Law, Vienna, Austria. *e-mail: antonia.praetorius@univie.ac.at; thilo.hofmann@univie.ac.at Nanomaterials are a popular object of environment, health and safety research, both from a legal and a practical perspective. While the applications of nanomaterials are extremely promising, their widespread presence in everyday products has raised concerns about potential risks and demand for adequate regulations. In the European Union, different legal acts contain specific provisions for nanomaterials1–4, including several product-specific regulations, such as for Cosmetics5, Food6, Biocides7 and Medical Devices8. Furthermore, a recent revision9 of the REACH Regulation on chemical substances10, which will apply as of 2020, introduces nano-specific provisions in the annexes. The scope of these regulations is specified by different definitions of the term “nanomaterial” since 2009 (see Table 1 and Supplementary Information Section 2). The Cosmetics, Food and Biocide Regulations contain their own individual nanomaterial definitions, whereas the Medical Devices and REACH Regulations define nanomaterials (or “nanoforms” in the case of REACH) according to the definition proposed by the European Commission in the Recommendation 201111 (see Table 1). It is crucial to note that—even though the Commission’s recommendation has attracted much attention and may even have been discussed more than the regulation-specific definitions12–17—the Recommendation 2011 in itself is a non-binding instrument. It puts no obligations on product manufacturers. Conversely, regulations are legally binding and directly applicable in the member states of the EU. Nanomaterial classification and regulation implies a twofold challenge. On the one hand, lawmakers must provide a meaningful legal framework including sensible definitions of nanomaterials; on the other hand, adequate analytical techniques are required to identify nanomaterials as defined by the regulations and to prove their presence in a product. The legal debate is embedded in a dynamic development, both from a regulatory and from a practical perspective. The Commission’s Recommendation 2011 has led to several reports on the definitions as well as the corresponding scientific background18–20. Furthermore, the Commission conducted a Public Consultation in 201721. ‘Adaptation clauses’ within the abovementioned regulations authorize the Commission to alter the current definitions by way of delegated acts, provided that the changes concern solely technical or scientific questions22,23. At the same time, there has been an immense effort in developing analytical methods for nanomaterial detection, quantification and characterization in product samples12,17,24–32 and the environment33–43. Considerable progress in nanomaterial-specific analytical methods has been achieved within recent years12,44–49, also due to the initiatives taken on the EU level as well as corresponding project funding. This Perspective takes an interdisciplinary approach to address both the legal and the practical dimensions of nanomaterial regulation, and analyses different elements (Supplementary Table 1) of current “nanomaterial” definitions at the EU level. Using interpretation techniques in accordance with the prevailing legal methodology, we provide a critical assessment of the legal clarity of the individual nanomaterial definitions and discuss the workability of the regulatory framework in light of existing analytical techniques. To interpret EU law, the European Court of Justice usually refers to the text of the provisions in question, taking into account its aim and purpose; moreover, it considers the different language versions of the text, which are all equally binding50–52. In rarer cases, the court has examined the drafting history53. These methods are helpful when dealing with general terms and ambiguous definitions, although some uncertainties may still prevail. Likewise, the exact classification of nanomaterials in complex samples (that is, consumer products or the environment) is no trivial task28,43. Difficulties arise from the fact that nanomaterials cannot be classified by an unambiguous substance identity54 (like, for example, lead or phenanthrene) but represent materials composed of substances possessing several properties (such as size, shape, composition), which are determined not by one single value but a distribution of values.
